titlestmt.titleproper: Marvin C. Griffin papers, Inclusive: 1940-2011, undated, Bulk: 1960-1999, undated

note.p: © 2021 The Texas Collection. All rights reserved.

profiledesc.creation: Finding Aid was generated by The Texas Collection staff, using the STAR Knowledge Center for Archives (SKCA) task that automatically creates EAD files from the Archive's SKCA catalog records.

did.head: Papers Summary
did.abstract: The Marvin C. Griffin papers include both written and recorded materials pertaining to Reverend Marvin Griffin's ministerial research and sermons, his political involvement, and his leadership in the Baptist Convention on the state and national level.

bioghist.head: Biography/Profile
bioghist.p: Marvin Collins Griffin was born in Wichita, Kansas, on February 20, 1923. He was the son of William Marvin Collins and Beulah Howell. Raised by his uncle and aunt near Dallas, Texas, Griffin felt a call to the ministry at the age of seven.

Griffin used his education to prepare for a career in preaching the gospel and fighting for African American civil rights. He spent his youth in the Dallas public school system. In 1943, Griffin graduated with a Bachelor of Arts degree from Bishop College. Four years later, he earned a degree in Divinity from Oberlin Graduate School of Theology. In 1955, Griffin became the first African American to graduate from Southwestern Baptist Theological Seminary when he earned a Master of Religious Education degree. In 1990, Griffin received his Doctorate of Ministry from Austin Presbyterian Theological Seminary.

Reverend Griffin began preaching in 1940 and was ordained two years later. While earning his degree from Oberlin, Griffin served as a professor at the Oklahoma Baptist School of Religion (1944-1948). His first significant pastoral assignment was New Hope Baptist Church in Waco. From 1951 to 1969, Griffin led his growing congregation in social activism within the community. He began an extensive radio broadcast ministry and led various marches and pickets in Waco.

In 1969, Griffin relocated to Ebenezer Baptist Church in Austin, Texas, where he remained for the next forty-two years. Once again, Griffin believed that his church should be involved in the spiritual and secular life of the community. He led the church’s efforts in creating the East Austin Economic Development Corporation (EAEDC) in 1998. This organization allowed the church to assist the underprivileged through housing programs, day care centers, counseling, and financial assistance. In 2002, the EAEDC building was renamed in honor of Marvin Griffin. Reverend Griffin retired from his pastorship of the Ebenezer Baptist Church on July 31, 2011.

In addition to his pastoral duties, Griffin was also involved in local politics and denominational affairs. He served as the first African American president of the Austin Independent School District Board of Directors when the schools were using buses to encourage desegregation. Griffin was also involved in the Missionary Baptist General Convention of Texas, he was the Director of the Christian Education Enrichment Program at the National Baptist Fellowship of Churches, and he served as a Director-Lecturer for the Teacher Training Department of the National Baptist Sunday School Congress.

Griffin married Lois King on August 5, 1944. They had three daughters: Marva Lois Carter, Gaynelle Jones, and Ria Griffin. Mrs. Lois Griffin passed away in 2006 and Marvin Griffin passed away on December 25, 2013.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: TheMarvin C. Griffin papers begin with Griffin's education in 1940 and end with his retirement in 2011. The Ministry series is the first and by far the largest series in the collection. It is divided into two subseries. The Personal subseries includes ministerial research for specific organizations as well as extensive research for radio broadcasts and sermons. The National Baptists subseries includes collected materials and reports from Griffin's involvement with various Baptist organizations. The Civic Engagement series includes records and research for Griffin's involvement with various political and civic organizations, mostly in the Austin area. The Subject Files series includes Griffin's research files relating to all aspects of his career. Finally, the Audio-Visual Materials series includes video tapes, reels and cassette tapes of sermons and speeches by Griffin and other prominent Baptist pastors.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Prior to the latest round of processing, the first donation of the collection was inventoried, processed, and arranged in folders and series according to the current processing standards. At that time, there did not appear to be any original organizational arrangement so the collection was arranged into four series. After this first round of processing was complete, a larger, second donation was given. Since the second donation appeared to be in original order while the first donation had artificial order imposed on it, new series were created to accommodate the incorporation of the first donation into the second. As a result, during current processing, materials from the first donation remained in their folders, retaining dates and titles from the first round of processing. Most of the materials from the second donation were received in folders with dates and titles reflecting their content, so they were placed in new folders with most of the titles and dates retained.

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: All requests for copying of materials must be submitted to The Texas Collection in writing. Please use the Request Form for Copying Materials sheet. Unpublished materials authored or otherwise produced by the creator (s) of this collection are in the public domain. There are no restrictions on use. Copyright status for other collection materials is unknown. Transmission or reproduction of materials protected by U.S. Copyright Law (Title 17, U.S.C.) beyond that allowed by fair use requires the written permission of the copyright owners. Works not in the public domain cannot be commercially exploited without permission of the copyright owners. Responsibility for any use rests exclusively with the user.

userestrict.head: Use/Re-use Restrictions
userestrict.p: This collection is open for research and contains records that were redacted for personal identifying information and other privacy concerns. Contact archivist for details.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Marvin C. Griffin papers, Accession #3837, Box #, Folder #, The Texas Collection, Baylor University.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Described by Casey Schumacher. Released on 2016-04-28.

Archivist''s Notes: Researchers interested in Reverend Griffin's sermons should be aware that most of the sermons in Series I, Subseries II are in binders sorted by book of the Bible and include an inventory in the front cover. For example, each binder of sermons on Genesis has an inventory listing of each sermon in that binder, including the sermon title and the date it was given.

relatedmaterial.head: Items in related collections
relatedmaterial.archref: [Waco] New Hope Baptist Church records, Inclusive: 1875-1988, Bulk: 1922-1985

relatedmaterial.bibref: Who’s Who in the South and Southwest: The Seventh Edition. Chicago: Marquis Publications, 1961.

bioghist.head: Biography/Profile
bioghist.p: The Ministry series contains the research and records of Marvin C. Griffin's pastoral career. The Personal subseries includes mostly research for sermons. The National Baptist subseries includes records of his involvement with various national Baptist conferences and committees. The series is in excellent condition.

Most of the sermons in Series I, Subseries II are in binders sorted by book of the Bible and include an inventory in the front cover. For example, each binder of sermons on Genesis has an inventory listing of each sermon in that binder, including the sermon title and the date it was given.

bioghist.head: Biography/Profile
bioghist.p: The Civic Engagement series includes records and administrative files for various political and civic organizations of which Marvin C. Griffin was an active member. The series is in good condition.

bioghist.head: Biography/Profile
bioghist.p: The Subject Files series includes Marvin C. Griffin's research for all areas of his career, sorted by organization or topic. There is also some biographical material on the Griffin family. The series is in good condition.

userestrict.head: Use/Re-use Restrictions
userestrict.p: This collection is open for research and contains records that were redacted for personal identifying information and other privacy concerns. Contact archivist for details.

bioghist.head: Biography/Profile
bioghist.p: The Audio-Visual Materials include mostly video tapes, reels and cassette tapes of sermons given by Marvin C. Griffin and other prominent Baptist pastors. There are some photographs and scrapbooks as well. Researchers should reference the supplementary document attached to this finding aid for a complete list of the cassette tapes in this series. The series is in good condition.
